title: Tangled
descriptions:
Tangled (2010) is a lively, heartfelt reimagining of the Rapunzel fairy tale, blending adventure, romance, and comedy. The story follows Rapunzel, a princess born with magical golden hair that can heal wounds and reverse aging when she sings a special song. As a baby, she is kidnapped by Mother Gothel, an old woman who covets the hair’s power to keep herself young. Gothel hides Rapunzel in a secluded tower deep in the forest and raises her as her own, warning her that the outside world is dangerous and forbidding her to leave.

Rapunzel grows up creative, curious, and yearning for freedom, her only companion a protective chameleon named Pascal. Every year on Rapunzel’s birthday, she sees thousands of floating lights rise in the night sky. Unaware they are lanterns launched by her true parents—the king and queen—hoping their lost daughter will return, Rapunzel dreams of leaving the tower for just one day to see the lights up close. Gothel dismisses her wish and manipulates her with guilt and fear.

Meanwhile, a charming thief named Flynn Rider (real name Eugene Fitzherbert) steals the royal crown from the castle with the help of two brutish brothers, the Stabbingtons. Escaping a pursuit led by the determined palace horse Maximus, Flynn stumbles upon Rapunzel’s hidden tower and climbs in to hide. Rapunzel knocks him out with a frying pan, then hides his satchel containing the crown. Recognizing an opportunity, she strikes a deal: if Flynn takes her to see the lanterns, she’ll return his satchel. Reluctantly, Flynn agrees, expecting to ditch her and retrieve the crown later.

Their journey through forests, rivers, and villages becomes a series of surprises. In the Snuggly Duckling tavern—seemingly full of fearsome thugs—Rapunzel discovers the patrons all have dreams of their own, and with her disarming kindness she wins them over. Inspired by her spirit, they help the pair escape when guards and the Stabbingtons arrive. Amid narrow escapes and a thrilling chase through a flooding ravine, Rapunzel and Flynn begin to bond. Flynn reveals his orphaned past and the false persona he adopted to survive, while Rapunzel gains confidence in her own abilities and the joy of experiencing the world for the first time.

Mother Gothel, realizing Rapunzel has left, schemes to manipulate her back into the tower. She secretly aligns with the Stabbingtons, planning to turn Rapunzel against Flynn. After Rapunzel and Flynn share a tender evening on a boat beneath the lantern-filled sky, Rapunzel begins to recognize feelings of love—and a growing sense of who she might truly be. Seeing the kingdom’s sun emblem everywhere, she has flashes of recognition connecting it to her childhood.

Gothel’s plot springs into action: the Stabbingtons lure Rapunzel with a lie that Flynn has abandoned her for the crown, and Flynn is captured. Heartbroken and confused, Rapunzel returns with Gothel to the tower, believing the outside world has betrayed her. Back at home, however, a mosaic triggers Rapunzel’s memories, and she pieces together the truth: she is the lost princess, and Gothel stole her for the magic in her hair. Summoning courage, Rapunzel confronts Gothel, vowing to never again be used for her power.

Meanwhile, Maximus helps Flynn escape imprisonment, and he races to the tower to save Rapunzel. Gothel, desperate, ties Rapunzel and prepares to flee forever. Flynn arrives and tries to free her, but Gothel stabs him. Rapunzel offers a bargain: she will willingly stay with Gothel forever if she can heal Flynn. As she reaches for him, Flynn makes a devastating choice for her freedom—he cuts Rapunzel’s hair with a shard of glass. The magic dies; Rapunzel’s hair turns brown and loses its power. Gothel rapidly ages and, in a panic, falls from the tower, disintegrating into dust. Rapunzel cradles Flynn as he dies in her arms.

In her grief, Rapunzel cries, and a single tear—still infused with the sun’s magic—falls on Flynn’s cheek and heals him, resurrecting him. With Gothel gone, Rapunzel reunites with the king and queen in an emotional homecoming. The kingdom celebrates the return of its princess, the Stabbingtons are dealt with, and Flynn, abandoning his old alias for his true name, Eugene, begins a new life by Rapunzel’s side.

The film closes on a note of joy: Rapunzel, no longer confined, embraces love, family, and her own agency. The themes of identity, trust, and the courage to leave the familiar intertwine with humor—
